executive_summary: Pet stores prospered in recent years as households have become more financially stable and pet ownership has risen. Pet parents have increasingly lavished their pets with premium food products, designer pet accessories and luxury grooming services. The industry has expanded despite mounting competition from supermarkets, mass merchandisers and online retailers. These competitors offer similar products at greater convenience and competitive prices. Traditional brick-and-mortar stores have successfully positioned themselves as pioneers and exclusive providers of high-quality food and additional service offerings, like grooming or daycare.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Small Pet Stores Contend with Rising Competition
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Traditional pet stores are typically small-scale and independently owned, with more than half employing fewer than ten workers. Small retailers often compete by catering to a specific niche market within a regional area. These small stores endured competition from internal big-box retailers and external competitors, such as mass merchandisers, supermarkets and online retailers. These retailers serve as a one-stop shop, allowing pet owners to buy groceries anywhere.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Pet Wellness Becomes a Growing Trend
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Consumers are increasingly conscious of their pets' health and wellness, leading to greater demand for high-quality, organic and natural pet foods. Owners are more willing to invest in premium products perceived as healthier options. There's a growing interest in pet supplements and specialized diets, such as grain-free or hypoallergenic options, reflecting broader human health and wellness trends.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Largest Pet-Owner Group is Millennials
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Many millennials can afford to move out and live independently as their income levels climb. Also, steady income streams enable pet parents to spend more confidently on their pets. According to the American Pet Products Association's 2021-2022 National Pet Owners Survey, an estimated 70.0% of US households—equivalent to 90.5 million households—own a pet. As Generation Z enters adulthood, this group expands its pet ownership.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Number of Pets Has Climbed
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: As Generation Z enters adulthood, this group expands its pet ownership. Individuals getting married later in life also obtain pets in the interim, making younger people a key market. Muddy Paws Rescue and the Best Friends Animal Society reported a 1,000.0% jump in applications since 2020. Pet ownership skyrocketed as consumers sought companionship from animals.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: A boost in pet ownership will lead to higher demand for discretionary and nondiscretionary products and services, like food, treats and toys. Recently, owners have become more willing to spoil their pets, which benefits revenue for pet stores. Growing spending on pets is correlated to the growing trend of pet humanization. Owners treat their pets like family members, often called pet parents.

Cat ownership has grown faster than dog ownership, as cats' lower maintenance nature has fit nicely with consumers' busy schedules and desires for convenience. While cats have climbed in popularity, cat owners spend less on average than dog owners, which limits growth. As home ownership grows sluggishly, cat adoptions may increasingly be seen as a more affordable alternative to dog adoptions.

Since full-time jobs no longer occupy retired baby boomers, they tend to adopt more pets or place a higher emphasis on pampering pets. This demographic tends to spend liberally on caring for their pets. A growing share of baby boomers crossing the retirement threshold will spur demand for pets and pet-related products, helping pet stores generate additional revenue through the end of 2029.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Growing Demand for Premium Products is Lifting Profit
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: According to the American Pet Products Association's 2023-24 National Pet Owners Survey, US pet owners' most frequently purchased pet food is premium, generic and natural. Pets have become more humanized in recent years and their status as part of the family has increased, as has the spending on their care. Natural products, especially pet food, will expand in popularity as owners increasingly emphasize their pets' diets to improve pet health.

industry_definition: Pet stores sell a variety of pets, including dogs, cats, fish and birds. Stores also sell pet foods and supplies, such as collars, leashes, health and beauty aids, shampoos, medication, toys, containers, kennels and furniture. Some stores also offer pet services, such as grooming, training and daycare.
key_trends: Price, product range, customer service and location are key. Since most pet products are identical, price and pet services are the primary competitive edges.

Mass merchandisers and online stores increased external competition. In response, many brick-and-mortar stores have boosted their online presence by establishing a website, social media accounts and mobile apps.

Economic growth boosts spending on premium pet products and services. Despite this growth, traditional brick-and-mortar stores struggle with mounting pricing pressures from online retailers, mass merchandisers and discount department stores.

Exclusive niche pet products will help diversify price competition. Most pet stores are small-scale, so niche product marketing will become more vital because it assists pet stores in positioning themselves apart from the competition.
Large pet stores garner a rising revenue share through websites as more customers feel comfortable purchasing online. To maintain foot traffic, smaller stores must offer unique products and services.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Consumers in this age group are children, teenagers and young adults. They commonly have restricted or no income, so they cannot spend much on pet products. Parents usually buy pets when their kids ask for them.
This age group typically has families or children wishing to have family pets. According to the American Pet Products Association, 38.0% of households with children under 18 own at least one pet.
Consumers in this age group are often the key financial providers of the household and are responsible for household pet expenditures.
The younger members of this customer segment had just entered their retirement ages and are more likely to have lived individually.

products_and_services.product_description: This segment covers a wide range of products, such as dry and wet food for dogs and cats, bird feed, crickets and worms for reptiles and other treats and supplements for several different household pets.

This segment includes live animals, over-the-counter medicines, food bowls, collars and leashes, pet clothing, brushes and combs, shovels and scoopers, cat litter, bird cages and reptiles, travel carriers and other pet accessories.
Pet services include full-service grooming, haircuts, baths, toenail trimming and tooth brushing, excluding veterinary services.

Pet stores sell various products, such as books, sporting goods, recreational equipment, lawn and garden equipment and supplies. Many pet stores also sell non-industry products to provide added convenience to customers.

tier_1_suppliers: Animal Food Production in the US
Toy, Doll & Game Manufacturing in the US
Dog & Pet Breeders in the US
Specialty Pet Food Production in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Livestock Production Support Services in the US
tier_2_buyers: Pet Grooming & Boarding in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_title: As households adopt more cats and dogs, sales of pet-related goods swell
demand_determinants.determinant_description: As households adopt more cats and dogs, sales of pet-related goods, including foods, medicines, accessories and services, swell.

business_locations.location_description: The region is the most populated in the United States, with one-quarter of the nation's population.
An establishment located further away from town is at a disadvantage compared to one in the center of a town.
The two most populated states in the region are New York and Pennsylvania because they have some of the most populated cities in the United States.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The Act deems it an offense to open a pet shop unless granted a license.
The Act protects certain animals from inhumane treatment and neglect.
The FDA oversees the safety of pet food sold in stores.

basis_points.basis_description: Price, product range, customer service and location are key competitive factors.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases consist of pet food and supplies
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases consist of pet food and supplies.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Pet stores rely on employees to provide service
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Employees are crucial in pet stores.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Pet stores sell both discretionary and non-discretionary products
volatility_points.volatility_description: While purchasing a pet is discretionary, a large proportion of expenditure on a pet is typically non-discretionary.

FAQs.question: How is your company targeting millennial consumers, who account for the largest portion of pet owners?
FAQs.answer: Marketing to millennial audiences may increase sales.

FAQs.question: How has your business adapted to the growth of online sales in recent years?
FAQs.answer: Providing incentives to purchase in-store may grow brick-and-mortar revenue.
